block.p: In Albany, New Oversight for Agencies New York State lawmakers capped the last day of the session by passing a plan to intensify oversight of the state's scandal-plagued public authorities, whose multibillion-dollar operations have long operated with little scrutiny. The Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki also reached agreement on an incentive package for businesses in Lower Manhattan.

Morgan Stanley Might Rehire Ex-President John J. Mack, the former president of Morgan Stanley who left after a power struggle in 2001, is in discussions with the board over his return as chief executive. But Mr. Mack is said to want two former executives who left during Philip J. Purcell's management shake-up to return with him.

3 Camden Boys Found Dead The father of one of three boys who vanished from Camden's hardscrabble streets made a horrifying discovery when he lifted the trunk of a car parked near where the boys were last seen and found his son and two playmates dead.
Tom Cruise, Unbound The actor's lecturing of Matt Lauer on ''Today'' was refreshing, a display of kookiness that certainly will not help his career, Alessandra Stanley writes.
New Column on Poker A weekly column by James McManus explores the world of poker, from low-stakes home games to Texas hold 'em tournaments and the World Series of Poker.

Dear, Can You Shush the Art? The newly popular genre of video art is not exactly easy to live with. In fact, the works are so cacophonous that even the most avid collectors must keep them set to ''off'' most of the time.
The Race to Alaska Rivers of ice are receding and melting permafrost is forcing roads to buckle. Is the reason global warming or something else? Tourists aren't waiting to find out.

Politics via a Sitcom First there was the ''South Park'' conservative -- that new breed of irreverent Republican voter. But another sitcom, ''King of the Hill,'' offers a more complex portrayal of small-town voters.
